dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little boy gazes out into the storm. Nervous, eager, sw Meet GEORGE DENBROUGH (9).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it's not too bad out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will (13), his older brother,   sits up in bed propped ag a pile of pillows, surrounded   by tissues and sheets of newspaper. HEADLINES and TOYS   tell us this is the late October, 1987 to be exact. He   puts finishing touches on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such a wuss. I'd come if I weren't dying. Now get the paraffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cellar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it to float or not, Georgie? Go on. Storm's not gonna last forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George jumps up obediently and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George hurries downstairs. He catches a glimpse of their mother, SHARON DENBROUGH (30s) in the parlor playing pian an earthy beauty transported to another world while she plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's stomach sinks as he comes face to face with THE CELLAR DOOR -- the only thing between George and the mons in the basement of his imagination -- IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WALKIE-TALKIE SQUAWKS next to Will. The sarcastic walki talkie filtered voice of RICHIE "TRASHMOUTH" TOZIER (12), neighbor, filters through the plastic speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy-boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, annoyed, picks up the walkie-talkie.   While lookin through his rain blasted window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trashmouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wave at each other. Richie, bug-eyed glasses, turns wave into a middle-finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you were sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it mortal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flinging it open, George ventures his arm into the DARK V He gropes around and finds the LIGHT SWITCH. Nothing. Geo snatches his arm back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, balls. The power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark basement glares back at him, taunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will coughs hard into a tissue. Half-impatient, half-joki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Georgie and I are making a paper boat. Got to go-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait-!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will turns off the walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George rubs the gooseflesh on his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting it. I'm going to get it. I'm going in. I'm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steels himself and plunges into the void.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George scrambles down four steps to THE CELLAR SHELF and sifts through junk as fast as he can: SHOE-POLISH, RAGS, dusty bag of colored BALLOONS, a broken FLASHLIGHT, two mostly empty bottles of WINDEX, and an old can of TURTLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stops and gazes upon the CARTOON TURTLE with hypno wonder. CUT TO POV of something lurking in recesses of th basement, watching GEORGE framed in the light of the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sensing this, George snaps out of it, grabs the BOX OF PARAFFIN near the back of the shelf, and hurries back up stairs, slamming the door in our/It's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will melts a chunk of paraffin with a match in a ceramic bowl, then dips his finger into the hot liquid and smears wax along the sides of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just don't get any on my blankets or Mom'll freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George dips his finger and spreads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They finish up and Will gives the boat to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go. She's all yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Captain, ain't   ya? Captains call their boats   she. Now put on your rain stuff or   you'll wind up stuck in bed like   your stupid brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both grin, the cozy room full of cheerful brotherly love. George kisses Will on the cheek, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Will looks to the rain-lashed window, piano stil playing. He's suddenly filled with a sense of foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DEAD TRAFFIC LIGHT sways overhead, its dripping black lenses gazing back at A BOY IN A YELLOW SLICKER AND RED GALOSHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie races down the street past dark houses after his PAPER BOAT, which sluices along a gutter swollen with rus rainwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain taps on George's hood sounding to his ears like rain a shed roof, a comforting almost cozy sound. The buckles his galoshes make a merry jingle as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat whistles past a blockade of sawhorses marked DEP DERRY PUBLIC WORKS, where a gouge in the blacktop sends i sweeping diagonally across toward a STORM DRAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George races after, trying to grab the boat before it's swallowed up with all the rainwater. He SLIPS AND SPILLS the blacktop, crying out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PAPER BOAT surfs up to the drain, circles around twic and goes in. George look ready to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's gonna kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to the drain and peers in, water falling in darkness. A dank hollow sound comes from within. Suddenly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EYES PEER BACK AT HIM -- from THE GREASY WHITE FACE OF A CLOWN. Not Bozo, or Ronald McDonald, but something more o world, freakish, like that of a 19th-century acrobat -- b lithe, almost child-like. Meet PENNYWISE aka BOB GRAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George recoils back, shocked by Pennywise's presence. A VOICE, a perfectly pleasant and reasonable voice, rises u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD WOMAN watches him from the kitchen window of a hou just behind the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO: POV from the OLD WOMAN's house. She turns her attention back to her cat, scraping out the wet innards o can of tuna into a plate on the window sill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George expression mellows from fear to child-like wonder, like he's seeing a circus bear balanced on a ball .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Why the storm of course. Just bleeeew me away. It blew the whole circus away. How'd you like to join the circus, Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faint, off-key sound of CALLIOPE MUSIC can be heard. George inches closer to the storm drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there cotton candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cotton candy? Oh yes. Cotton candy and bearded women and elephant shit and all the balloons a little boy could want. You like balloons, don't you Georgie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure do. Do they float?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George takes one last fatal step forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Float? Oh indeed they do, Georgie. Indeed they do. Everything down here floats. And when you're down here with us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clown's sing-songy voice curdles into something horri primal even, as George's arm is seized by Pennywise's unusually LONG arm and CLAW-like hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU'LL FLOAT TOO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's SCREEEEEAAAAAM rings through the sewers as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO the OLD WOMAN's POV again. The cat devours its foo the old woman pleased with his appetite does not notice..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACK FOCUS... Georgie's rag doll body flung left and righ Pennywise feeds on him and tries to pull him through the metal grate into the sewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaring, percussive MUSIC crescendos over a wide shot of glacier-cut mountains. Then, SILENCE.  TITLE CARD:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OFF glacier-cut mountains to reveal the TOWN OF DERRY MAINE, settled on a crosscut of the Penobscot River and Kenduskaeg stream. It's a sturdy, picturesque Northeaster town like any other, its rough-hewn industrial past bleed through a gentrified, decaying present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TILT STRAIGHT DOWN to HANLON ABATOIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVERAL multi-acre, manure filled sheep pens stand empty. One has 50 sheep ready for slaughter, a path leading from pen grows narrower as it feeds into an industrial complex designed for slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEROY HANLON (50s) works to move the sheep into line whil his son MIKE HANLON (13) watches from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of this, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People need to eat.   Now open the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike opens the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you feel if you were one of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy, haunted by this thought answers gruffly-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humans aren't raised to be food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if he were lying, that humans sometimes ARE raised for food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheep flood into a thinner pathway leading to the interior of the complex. Leroy watches them as does Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyday, watching them stupidly walk into that killing pen. This isn't a normal kid's life. You won't even let me go to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy takes the cattle bolt, places it on the head of the first sheep. WOOMPH. The sheep drops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why would you want to be in public school with the rest of those people down below, in Derry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it to Mike, expectantly. Mike dispassionately ta the mechanism and approaches a sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I want to be in boring classes with other boring kids and draw pictures in text books and play baseball and go to dances and grind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places it on the head of the next sheep, but can't bri himself to pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy does it for him.   WOOMPH.   The sheep drops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, son. I get it. But you aren't like those people. We may work with sheep, but those people are sheep. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last point Leroy believes in like gospel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors fling open and ROWDY 6TH, 7TH, and 8TH GRADERS spil out. Books are hurled in the trash, papers strewn all ove the recess yard -- summer is officially commenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swept up among this madness is...  WILL DENBROUGH (13)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handsome, gangly, red-headed, the memory of his brother s fresh. He walks with his dorky friends, all talking over other: EDDIE KASPBRAK, his EPI-PEN JR. (an adrenaline injector for kids with life-threatening allergies) holste in his medicine-filled fannypack; STAN URIS (12), a trim tidy Jewish kid who dresses like a mini-accountant; and RICHIE TOZIER, the neighbor with the walkie-talkie, a com book and video game freak with bug-eye glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What work?                        So long suckas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie flips off the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony. Your Bar Mitzvah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes you officially a man right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of. I read verses. From      Then a seventh dimensio the Torah.                        door opens up and Stan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I don't need a Bar Mitzvah for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie howls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just your mom's Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vogue man. It's all perfumed. I put on my 3-D glasses and it's like you're there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie "motor boats" the air in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE on a GROUP OF fashionably dressed GIRLS NEARBY. The bigger, heavier one of the group notices someone off scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the ho-bag, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN to see BEVERLY MARSH (13) a dazzling cloud of auburn and lovely green-gray eyes. Her clothes aren't as nice as group of popular girls, but she holds her head high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the one all the eighth grade boys talk about.  GIRL #1                     GIRL #1 (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say she gives the best     Probably the only way she bjs.                            afford those rags she wea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly sees the girls as Girl #1 puts Gretta's rings on fingers. Sensing trouble, she turns around and ducks righ back into school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey cock breath, come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN back to WILL and his dorky friends.   Eddie stops dea POINTING TO-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, she's still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RABBI'S WIFE, sleepless and desperate, lurks on the e of school property, scanning the throngs of departing kid with desperate eyes. Next to her, a FRONT LAWN MARQUEE re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think she's thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she expects her son to just walk out of the school with the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right, Dorsey Coen's been living in home ec these last three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not going to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure they will. In a ditch. All decomposed, covered in worms and maggots and smelling like your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie is CHECKED TO THE PAVEMENT by TRAVIS BOWERS (16), sadistic tower of muscle. His glasses fall off and a pile comics and video game magazines spill from his back pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry chode. Didn't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travis kicks the glasses away. His thug sidekicks laugh: SNATCH HUGGINS (15), PATRICK HOCKSTETTLER (17) and VICTOR CRISS (15) -- one a lunkhead oaf, another a perpetually giggly fire-starting sociopath, and the last one a scrap scab junk yard dog type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor grabs Stan's yarmulka and tosses it into the windo a departing bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frisbee, fuck nut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snatch burps in Eddie's face. Eddie wilts under the smell Will scoops up the remains of Richie's glasses, smashed b the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suck, Bowers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travis and his goons turn. They glare at Will menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone around them stops and watches, waiting for Will respond. Eddie gives Will a look to shut it. He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought so. You got a free ride this year because of your little brother. But ride's over, Denbrough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This summer's gonna be a hurt train, for you and your faggot friends. (to Snatch and Victor) Let's roll. We got a lard ass to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens by the dumpsters and out peaks BEN HANSCOM ( the "lard ass" in question, making sure the coast is clea He wears an oversized sweatshirt and a pair of girly high waisted blue jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soooo, you gonna let me go by or is there a secret password or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to see Beverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps aside. Beverly tip-toes past, lighting a cigaret like a pro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sorry"'s not much of a password. Now "kittyhawk," that's a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballyhoo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnburner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly smiles and offers Ben a smoke. He refuses. She sh and blows a smoke ring in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're worried about Bowers and his merry band of a-holes hassling you, don't. I saw them all leave out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the new kid right? I'm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly Marsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little too quick. His ears turn red with embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know `cuz we were in social studies. Together, in the same class. You know, like the constitution test, and stuff. (realizing he's vomiting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bev smiles, knowingly. It's clear he likes her. Ben notic FAINT YELLOW BRUISE on her forearm. Bev notices him notic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Ben's look) I slipped in the shower. What's your excuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell on three boxes of donuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, see ya around Ben from sosh class. "Get laid in the shade."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, you too, Beverly. "Stay cool."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches her go, totally smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: K.I.T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust collects on the piano in the living room. A stale qu suffocates the house. The only sound the ticking of a clo and the distant yelling of playing children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Denbrough laces his shoes. As he leaves his room, he notices the door to George's room is open, his FATHER, ZA DENBROUGH (30s), lost in thought notices him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Champ. Going out to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will looks like he wants to say more, but doesn't have th words to articulate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumping down the stairs and rounding the corner, he sees catatonic Mother, silhouetted by the midday light, sittin the darkness, staring blankly at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing accustomed to his parent's lack of communication, sifts through a PILE OF UNOPENED MAIL on the dining table finds his report card. Opens it. All A's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my report card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the paper limply in his hands. She doesn't acknowledge him and instead gets up and slides the doors to the piano room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, Richie, Will, and Stan scramble in the front door feral animals. An enormous 300-pound woman sits in the li room doing a puzzle on her own stomach. SONIA KASPBRAK (4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kaspbrak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They raid the kitchen, stuffing Capri Suns, Ding Dongs, whatever snacks they can find into their backpacks. Mrs. Kaspbrak calls from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie-bear, where are you boys off to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie-bear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will elbows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just my backyard, Mrs. K. We got a new, uh, badminton set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just don't go rolling around too much on that grass, sweetie. Especially if it's just been cut. You know how your allergies get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he cute, boys? So cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wiggles her fat toes at him. He's mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutest boy we know, Mrs. Kaspbrak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miss America of cute boys. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast as they came the boys blow out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, Rich, and Eddie speed past the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All green globes, curving iron staircases, and shadowy ch A librarian, MRS. STARRET (50s) places a stack of books i front of Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it summer vacation? I would think you'd be ready to take a break from the books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it in here. It's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at a newspaper behind her: "BODY FOUND NEAR CA NOT THAT OF COEN YOUTH, BORTON ANNOUNCES." Safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Starret smiles sweetly at this large boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, even with all this terrible disappearing of kids business, a boy should be with his friends, outside, having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts stamping his books.      CHUCHUNP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll try, Mrs. Starret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are all these for anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reading about the history of this place. You know how many spooky things have--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ONE-ARMED OLD MAN comes up behind them wearing a U.S.S. Indianapolis cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the children's section?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHUCHUMP.   Mrs. Starret slides Ben his stack of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly opens her fridge. There's nothing in it but a plastic jug of margarine, some half-molded white bread, a suspect milk. She sniffs the milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly sips the milk, leaving a wholesome white mustache her upper lip. She looks up to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Mother, MRS. MARSH (30s), a former prom queen long si faded, watching her. Studying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bev.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Marsh sounds like she might be on sedatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had your monthly, yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bleeding, between your legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
